ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned interesting theoretical frameworks for understanding distributed computing.
I learned to think about distributed systems in a novel way. This has changed my understanding of how different agents interact with each other, even outside of large-scale systems.
I learned a fair amount of proof writing techniques, and a lot about the theory behind distributed systems.
knowledge of distributed systems research
I learned a lot about Distributed algorithms, I found the problem sets very challenging yet interesting enough to think about.

All about theory of distributed systems. There's some really cool topics. If you're a fan of algorithms or computability, you will definitely take away something from this course and find it enjoyable.

- well-known results in distributed systems
- reasoning about limits of distributed system algorithms

I learned about how to analyze distributed systems, and how to prove various things can or cannot work for distributed systems with various assumptions in place. You can look at Prof Aspnes posted notes to see generally what is covered.
theory of distributed systems
Concepts of distributed systems.
The theory of distributed systems (message passing and shared memory systems)
distributed system algorithms
Message passing, shared memory, paper reading and presentation
Theoretical knowledge of distributed systems.
Introduction to distributed systems concepts and algorithms. Psets were good practice in practicing intuition and applying algorithms from class (or from literature)

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I personally felt that the curriculum of this class was excessively theoretical. We certainly learned a lot about the theory of distributed systems as advertised, but there was essentially no connection back to how the material in question could be remotely relevant to real-world distributed computing problems. Additionally, while it was nice that there were no exams and only 5 problem sets, I felt that this decreased my retention of course information because there was no incentive to build real understanding of the material beyond what was necessary to complete the short problem sets.

Strength: Super interesting topics. Hes a good lecturer. 
Weakness: Very niche topics related to profs research. Some times can move too fast. While its nice the workload was super low, feel like having midterms would keep the class more engaged.

The course notes were incredible! I learned so much by just reading them. 

On the other side of the coin, the course notes were so good that I didn't go to lecture or engage in the class significantly outside of them.
No weaknesses. Course overall was very good.
could be improved with perhaps an interesting project, other than this it is pretty complete. One think that could be improved is grading speed and amount of feedback given.

The lectures can cover a lot of ground, and sometimes the proofs are hard to follow.
It would be useful if the main objective/ result of the proof is explicitly stated before starting the proof, and once it's completed.
A five minute summary of the main results from the previous lecture would also be useful.
Interesting problem sets.

strength:  The instructor was organized, well prepared, and used class time efficiently.
weakness: sometimes I hardly keep up with course content, due to the difficult and obscure knowledge
strength: assignments are interesting to do; weakness: lectures can be fast-paced and ambiguous sometimes

The strengths: First, professor Aspnes provided inclusive notes. You can find everything you need in the notes. Second, professor Aspnes created a discord channel for this course and always stood by, answering numerous questions about the homework, which is also really helpful. Third, the lecture was well-recorded. You can refer to the video whenever you want. 
The weakness: The course content takes a lot of time to understand. Although each problem set has only two or three problems, it can take days to figure everything out.

Professor is very knowledgeable and kind! He was very helpful and patient on Ed. The recordings and homework were very helpful. One weakness is that Professor's handwritten class notes were not clear from time to time, so I would suggest that Professor uses PPT in class :)

The notes were very valuable and the lectures were also fresh and provided new material to the notes, to some degree. I think that engagement could be improved on when it comes to students and participating in lectures.

Strengths: distributed is (one of) Aspnes' area of expertise. He is a pretty humorous lecturer (an occurring image is adversaries as triangles with devil horns and pointy teeth), and his lecture notes are accessibly written. Weaknesses: it was hard to keep up with everything covered in the lecture, and the topic and pace make it hard to follow if you fall behind

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Probably not. I felt that it was not concrete enough to be useful in my real-life career aspirations.
For an easy grade this is a good course. But can be quite complex, and quite easy to fall behind.
This is a very good course if you need a filler class to not attend.
Yes, Aspnes is a solid lecturer and distributed systems has many interesting problems. Definitely a good foundation for anyone going into theory.
Yes. Great course and a great professor.
yes, it is a fundamental course for people working in distributed systems
Yes. Lectures are very interesting as well as problem sets.
yes, it'a a good theoretical course which introduces a lot of information about distributed systems.
yes, interesting problems.

I would recommend this class if you are interested in the details of how distributed systems theory works. There are a lot of proofs and the topics can be quite sophisticated. A lot of times I found myself understanding the more general overview of a particular topic at the start of lectures, but near the middle of the lecture I would start getting quite confused. This is definitely one of those classes where you get how much work you put in, and is quite chill.
I would recommend it to students who are good at logical thinking and want to learn theoretical knowledge of distributed systems.
yes, but note that this class is heavily proof-based

Yes if you like algorithms. This course is proof-based, not coding-based. It will cover a lot of interesting and classic distributed algorithms and problems. It gives an overview. The course pace is pretty fast. Almost every lecture covers one topic. Although you don't need to understand all of them to figure out the problem sets, you still could take days to figure them out.
Yes. The intellectual challenge was great!

If you enjoy proofs or want to improve them, this is a nice class to practice intuition. If you enjoyed algorithms and trying to come up with/understand new algorithms, there's lots of them in this class! Note that this a proofs class, not a coding class
